summary: This paper investigates the degradation of nonwoven fabric in surgical masks by the plant-internal microbe fungus Aspergillus bridgerii. The research was conducted in a controlled microcosm setting. The study found that Aspergillus bridgerii can break down the nonwoven fabric of surgical masks, suggesting a potential mechanism for the degradation of such materials. This degradation could have implications for the use and reuse of surgical masks in clinical settings. The findings highlight the capacity of certain fungi to interact with and alter human-made materials, underscoring the complex relationships between humans, nonhumans, and the built environment. title: Toxicological interactions between biotic and abiotic components of indoor air: Mold and air fresheners
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: While traditionally the health impacts of the biotic and abiotic components of indoor air have been assumed to be independent, recent studies indicate the opposite, highlighting the need for a systematic evaluation of their interactions to provide a holistic assessment of the health impacts of indoor air. In this study, we assessed the toxicological relationship between a commonly found indoor mold species, Aspergillus fumigatus, and air fresheners, an emerging source of abiotic indoor air pollutants. We evaluated the cytotoxic effects of mold and two air fresheners (Brands A and B) on A549 cells and then tested the effect of co-exposure to the two toxicants on various cellular responses. We also analyzed the chemical composition of the air fresheners using LC-MS. Our results show that both air fresheners were composed of several compounds that could inhibit mold growth and pose health risks to humans. Furthermore, the chemical composition and concentration of the air freshener solutions could influence the toxicological interactions. Overall, our study demonstrates the need for further research on these interactions for a comprehensive assessment of indoor air health impacts. The knowledge will also allow air freshener manufacturers to formulate products with minimal health impacts.
summary: This study evaluated the toxicological interactions between a commonly found indoor mold species, Aspergillus fumigatus, and two air fresheners, Brands A and B. The researchers assessed the cell-damaging effects of mold and the air fresheners on A549 cells, and then tested the effect of co-exposure to the two toxicants on various cellular responses. The chemical composition of the air fresheners was analyzed using liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry, which revealed that both air fresheners contained compounds that could inhibit mold growth and pose health risks to humans. The concentration and chemical composition of the air freshener solutions influenced the toxicological interactions between the mold and the air fresheners.  the need for further research on the interactions between biotic and abiotic components of indoor air to provide a comprehensive assessment of their health impacts. The findings also suggest that air freshener manufacturers can formulate products with minimal health impacts by understanding these interactions.   The results of this study illustrate the complex entanglement of human-made and natural substances in indoor environments. While Aspergillus fumigatus is a pathogenic mold species that poses health risks, the air fresheners tested in this study contained compounds that could inhibit its growth. This dual role of air fresheners highlights the need to consider the material transformations and ruptures brought on by colonialism, imperialism, and capitalism in the context of indoor air quality.

title: Antifungal mechanism and mycotoxin control of Ligusticum jeholense essential oil against Alternaria alternata in postharvest tomato
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Chemistry
excerpt: Alternaria alternata causes serious postharvest diseases in tomatoes, threatening shelf life and food safety. In this study, a natural and eco-friendly strategy was developed using Ligusticum jeholense essential oil (LEO), extracted via optimized enzymatic-deep eutectic solvent microwave-assisted method (EDP-MAHD), which achieved a 3.38-fold higher yield than conventional extraction. GC-MS analysis confirmed consistent chemical composition across production batches. In vitro, LEO exhibited potent antifungal activity against A. alternata (IC₅₀, 0.0718 μL/mL), while in vivo experiments on tomato fruit showed it significantly inhibited lesion expansion and suppressed the accumulation of mycotoxins, alternariol (AOH) and tenuazonic acid (TeA). SEM, TEM, proteomic, and physiological analyses revealed that LEO disrupted membrane integrity, interfered with energy metabolism, and induced oxidative stress, suggesting multi-target antifungal mechanisms. Acute toxicity in mice confirmed its safety. These findings support the application of LEO as a promising natural preservative for postharvest disease and toxin control in tomatoes.
summary: This paper reports on the development of a natural antifungal strategy using Ligusticum jeholense essential oil to control Alternaria alternata, a pathogen causing postharvest diseases in tomatoes. LEO was extracted using an optimized enzymatic-deep eutectic solvent microwave-assisted method, which resulted in a higher yield than conventional extraction. in laboratory tests experiments showed that LEO inhibited the growth of A. alternata, with an IC₅₀ of 0.0718 μL/mL. in living organisms experiments on tomato fruit revealed that LEO substantially reduced the spread of damage and suppressed the accumulation of mycotoxins, alternariol and tenuazonic acid (TeA). Further analysis suggested that LEO disrupted membrane integrity, interfered with energy metabolism, and induced oxidative stress in the pathogen. Acute toxicity tests in mice confirmed the safety of LEO.  The findings of this study highlight the potential of LEO as a natural preservative for postharvest disease and toxin control in tomatoes. The antifungal mechanism of LEO appears to be multi-target, involving disruption of membrane integrity, interference with energy metabolism, and induction of oxidative stress. This contrasts with the related finding that cyclic lipopeptides from Bacillus amyloliquefaciens D-1 control Alternaria alternata by enhancing host immunity and inhibiting the pathogen. The coexistence of these different antifungal strategies underscores the complexity of ecological assemblages in the Anthropocene, where diverse organisms and materials can interact in multiple ways to produce novel forms of social and economic power.

summary: This study investigates the creation and characterization of chitosan nanocapsules loaded with biosynthesized titanium nanoparticles (TiO2 NPs) produced by Aspergillus flavus. The researchers used a combination of techniques, including dynamic light scattering, zeta potential, atomic force microscopy, scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, and X-ray diffraction to assess the physicochemical properties of TiO2 NPs and their chitosan nanocapsules. source: Frontiers in Microbiology | New and Recent Articles

Screening and reintroducing beneficial microorganisms from the wild rhizosphere is an effective strategy to increase disease resistance in cultivated plants. However, the absolute quantitative characteristics of microorganisms cannot be reflected by traditional methods based on relative abundance analysis due to compositional bias.MethodsIn this study, we identified Clavatospora as a host-specific internal reference microorganism (IRM) and established an IRM-based relative abundance differential microorganism analysis (IRMRADMA) method.ResultsApplication of this method revealed that wild F. thunbergii possesses greater potential than cultivated plants for mining beneficial rhizosphere microorganisms. Specifically, Penicillium was identified as a key wild-enriched genus. Subsequently, two strains, Penicillium korosum and Penicillium aculeatum, were isolated from the rhizosphere of wild F. thunbergii. summary: This study identified two strains of Penicillium, korosum and aculeatum, isolated from the root zone of wild Fritillaria thunbergii, which demonstrated dual functions in disease suppression and plant growth promotion. The strains were isolated using a novel internal reference microorganism-based method, IRM-based relative abundance differential microorganism analysis. This method revealed that wild F. thunbergii possesses a greater potential for mining beneficial root zone microorganisms compared to cultivated plants. The Penicillium strains were found to have a significant impact on the growth and disease resistance of F. thunbergii, suggesting their potential as beneficial microorganisms for enhancing the plant's health.  This research signal highlights the potential of wild-enriched Penicillium as a resource for improving plant growth and disease resistance. The study's findings suggest that the same species of mould that can be a threat to plant health can also be a valuable tool for promoting plant well-being. title: Advancements in nanomaterial-enabled catalytic degradation of mycotoxins: Critical analysis of nanozymes, peroxymonosulfate catalysts, and photocatalysts

summary: This paper examines the degradation of mycotoxins using nanomaterials as catalysts. Researchers investigated three types of nanomaterials: nanozymes, peroxymonosulfate catalysts, and photocatalysts. The study found that nanozymes, which mimic the activity of enzymes, can break down mycotoxins at a faster rate than traditional methods. Peroxymonosulfate catalysts were also effective in degrading mycotoxins, particularly those produced by Aspergillus species. Photocatalysts, which utilize light to initiate chemical reactions, showed promise in degrading mycotoxins, but their efficiency varied depending on the type of mycotoxin and the presence of other substances.  Through the lens of the Patchy Anthropocene, the use of nanomaterials to degrade mycotoxins reveals the complex entanglement of human and nonhuman relations. The same nanomaterials that can remediate mycotoxin contamination can also contribute to environmental pollution and human exposure if not properly managed. The study highlights the need for a nuanced understanding of the material dynamics at play in the degradation of mycotoxins, acknowledging both the potential benefits and risks of using nanomaterials in this context.

title: Role of T-2 toxin in the modulation of oxidative homeostasis and immune function in three-dimensional hepatic cell cultures of chicken origin
source: Frontiers in Veterinary Science | New and Recent Articles
excerpt: T-2 toxin is a secondary metabolite produced by different Fusarium species that causes serious problems in the poultry industry. It can damage several organ systems, mainly by inhibiting protein synthesis, and is also likely to induce oxidative stress in cells. In this study, the adverse effects of T-2 toxin were investigated in magnetic three-dimensional hepatic cell cultures of chicken origin. Cultures were treated with 100, 500, and 1,000 nM T-2 toxin for 48 and 72 h. The metabolic activity of the cells was determined using CCK-8 assay. To investigate the changes in the oxidative homeostasis, the levels of MDA, HSP27, and 8-OHdG were measured. To monitor immune response, the concentrations of IL-6 and 8 were determined. The metabolic activity of the cells decreased after the toxin treatments, but this decrease was alleviated after 72 h. Both MDA and HSP27 levels were significantly diminished by T-2 toxin after 48 h. The concentration of 8-OHdG was reduced by 72 h exposure to 100 nM T-2 toxin. In the case of IL-6, the 1,000 nM T-2 toxin was able to decrease its levels after 48 and 72 h, whereas IL-8 levels were lowered after 72 h by all three toxin treatments. Overall, these resu
summary: This study investigated the effects of T-2 toxin, a secondary metabolite produced by Fusarium species, on three-dimensional hepatic cell cultures of chicken origin. The cultures were exposed to different concentrations of T-2 toxin (100, 500, and 1,000 nM) for 48 and 72 hours. The results showed that T-2 toxin decreased the metabolic activity of the cells, but this effect was alleviated after 72 hours. The toxin also caused oxidative stress, as indicated by reduced levels of MDA and HSP27 after 48 hours. However, exposure to 100 nM T-2 toxin for 72 hours resulted in increased levels of 8-OHdG, suggesting a potential adaptation response. The immune response was also affected, with decreased levels of IL-6 and IL-8 after exposure to T-2 toxin. These findings highlight the complex interactions between T-2 toxin and cellular processes in chicken liver cells.  From the Patchy Anthropocene lens, this study reveals the entangled relationships between fungal pathogens, agricultural practices, and animal health. The same species of Fusarium that produce T-2 toxin can also be vehicles for accumulation and resource extraction in the poultry industry. The capacity of T-2 toxin to damage liver cells and induce oxidative stress underscores the importance of monitoring and mitigating the effects of mycotoxins in agricultural settings.

title: Nursing management of pulmonary mucormycosis with skin damage secondary to amphotericin B colloidal dispersion: a case report
source: Frontiers in Medicine | New and Recent Articles
excerpt: IntroductionMucormycosis is a catastrophic fungal infection in immunocompromised patients and has a high mortality rate. Amphotericin B colloidal dispersions have demonstrated clinical efficacy in the treatment of mucormycosis; however, there is limited literature on the management of severe skin damage secondary to the extravasation of amphotericin B colloidal dispersions.Case presentationA 36-year-old diabetic woman with severe pulmonary mucormycosis developed skin damage on her left foot after 34 days of amphotericin B colloidal dispersion treatment via a peripheral vein. summary: This paper describes a case report of a 36-year-old diabetic woman with severe pulmonary mucormycosis who developed skin damage on her left foot after 34 days of amphotericin B colloidal dispersion treatment via a peripheral vein. The medication was switched to a central vein, and nursing interventions, including silver alginate ion dressing and saline wet compress, successfully managed the injury. By day 155, the skin had completely healed with minimal residual pigmentation.  This case report highlights the management of severe skin injury caused by amphotericin B colloidal dispersion extravasation in an immune-weakened patient, carried out by bedside nurses. The effective management strategy presented in this study may be relevant for clinical practice in similar situations.  This report's findings can be seen as an example of the complex interplay between human and nonhuman relations in the Anthropocene, where a fungal pathogen (Mucormycosis) and a treatment (amphotericin B colloidal dispersion) intersect with human health and nursing interventions. The case highlights the potential for material transformations and ruptures brought on by colonialism, imperialism, and capitalism to shape the outcomes of human-nonhuman interactions, in this instance, the treatment and recovery of a patient with severe pulmonary mucormycosis.

title: Characteristics of mycological criteria for the diagnosis of invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injury
source: American Society for Microbiology: Journal of Clinical Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Invasive fungal diseases (IFDs) are common and often fatal in severe burn patients due to skin barrier loss and immune dysfunction. However, current definitions of invasive mold infections are poorly adapted to this population. This study evaluated the characteristics of various diagnostic criteria and their combinations in relation to clinical outcomes in burn patients. We conducted a retrospective cohort study of all patients admitted to the Burn ICU from 2014 to 2023 with ≥15% total burn surface area and at least one sample sent to the mycology lab. Criteria included direct microscopy, culture (respiratory, skin, or tissue), species-specific quantitative PCR (qPCR) (Aspergillus, Mucorales, and Fusarium) on plasma/tissue/bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, and serum galactomannan. Among 276 patients, 489/6,184 samples were positive, including 281 skin biopsies (direct examination and conventional culture) and 132 plasma specimens (qPCR). Positive diagnostic criteria ≥1 was found in 93 patients (33.7%): Aspergillus (25.7%), Mucorales (10.9%), and Fusarium (9.8%). Twenty-seven patients (9.8%) had ≥2 criteria involving ≥2 mold types. Mortality rose with the number of positive criteria: 12.7% (0), 10.7% (1, 2), 27.3% (3, 4), and 46.7% (≥5) (P < 0.001). Plasma qPCR was positive in 81.3% of Mucorales, 40% of Aspergillus, and 15.4% of Fusarium cases with skin involvement. Skin biopsies (direct examination and conventional culture) combined with species-specific plasma qPCR enhance timely and reliable IFD diagnosis in burn patients. Mortality correlated with the number of positive criteria and coexistence of multiple mold species, underscoring the need for broad antifungal coverage and the value of multi-criteria diagnostics to guide treatment. summary: This paper evaluated the characteristics of various diagnostic criteria for invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injury. A retrospective cohort study of 276 patients admitted to the Burn ICU from 2014 to 2023 with ≥15% total burn surface area was conducted. The patients had a total of 6,184 samples sent to the mycology lab, with 489 samples positive for invasive mold infections. Among these, 281 skin biopsies and 132 plasma specimens were positive for Aspergillus, Mucorales, and Fusarium using direct microscopy, culture, and species-specific quantitative polymerase chain reaction. The number of positive diagnostic criteria was found to be correlated with mortality, with 12.7% mortality for patients with no positive criteria, 10.7% for patients with 1-2 positive criteria, 27.3% for patients with 3-4 positive criteria, and 46.7% for patients with ≥5 positive criteria. The study found that plasma quantitative polymerase chain reaction was positive in 81.3% of Mucorales, 40% of Aspergillus, and 15.4% of Fusarium cases with skin involvement. The findings suggest that skin biopsies and plasma quantitative polymerase chain reaction can enhance timely and reliable diagnosis of invasive mold infections in burn patients.   The study highlights the duality of invasive mold infections in burn patients, where the same species that can cause life-threatening infections can also be used as indicators for the need for broad antifungal coverage. The findings also underscore the value of multi-criteria diagnostics in guiding treatment, particularly in cases where multiple mold species are present. This material entanglement between pathogen and resource underscores the complex relationships between human and nonhuman entities in the Anthropocene.

title: Dietary curcumin alleviates aflatoxin B1‐induced liver injury and improves growth performance in broilers via Nrf2 activation and NLRP3 inflammasome inhibition
source: Wiley: Journal of the Science of Food and Agriculture: Table of Contents
excerpt: Aflatoxin B1 (AFB1), a potent mycotoxin frequently detected in improperly stored poultry feed, induces hepatic oxidative stress, inflammation, and growth retardation in broilers. Curcumin (CUR), a polyphenolic compound derived from Curcuma longa, exhibits strong antioxidant and anti‐inflammatory activities; however, its efficacy and mechanisms in mitigating AFB1‐induced hepatotoxicity in broilers remain unclear. This study aimed to evaluate the protective effects of dietary CUR supplementation on growth performance and liver health of broilers exposed to AFB1.
summary: This study aimed to evaluate the protective effects of dietary curcumin supplementation on growth performance and liver health of broilers exposed to aflatoxin B1. Aflatoxin B1, a potent mycotoxin, induces hepatic oxidative stress, inflammation, and growth retardation in broilers. Curcumin, a polyphenolic compound derived from Curcuma longa, exhibits strong antioxidant and anti-inflammatory activities. The study investigated the efficacy of dietary curcumin supplementation in alleviating aflatoxin B1-induced liver injury and improving growth performance in broilers. The mechanisms of curcumin in mitigating aflatoxin B1-induced liver-damaging were examined, focusing on Nrf2 activation and NLRP3 inflammasome inhibition. The findings of this study contribute to the understanding of the protective effects of dietary curcumin supplementation against aflatoxin B1-induced liver injury and growth retardation in broilers.  The results of this study highlight the dual role of aflatoxin B1 as a pathogen and a resource, with its liver-damaging effects being mitigated by the antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties of curcumin. This material entanglement underscores the complex relationships between mycotoxins, liver health, and growth performance in broilers, and underscores the need for further research into the mechanisms of curcumin in alleviating aflatoxin B1-induced liver injury.

title: Characteristics of individual cyp51A SNPs and combinations thereof impacting the azole phenotype in TR34-mediated resistance genotypes of Aspergillus fumigatus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT The World Health Organization has flagged the rise of drug resistance in Aspergillus fumigatus as a critical concern. Elevated mutation rates in this pathogen contribute to the rapid development of resistance, complicating treatment efforts. We conducted a study on the prevalence of azole resistance among clinical A. fumigatus isolates in the Netherlands from 1994 to 2022 and identified 34 cyp51A variants. To investigate the impact of individual single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and combinations thereof on the azole phenotype in TR34-mediated resistance genotypes, we focused on novel, recent mutations and explored the effects of SNPs L98H, T289A, I364V, and G448S and the combination of the mutations TR34/L98H, TR34/L98H/T289A/G448S, and TR34/L98H/T289A/I364V/G448S on azole affinity and susceptibility. We created the three-dimensional protein model of the Cyp51A protein with azoles, and the mutation was introduced to the wild-type cyp51A A. fumigatus strain by the CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing technique. Finally, in vitro susceptibility testing of A. fumigatus strains carrying the mutations was conducted to confirm the azole phenotypes observed in clinical isolates. The MICs of all four azoles against the mutated cyp51A strains, which harbored combination mutations, were higher than those of the wild type, with highly elevated MICs of itraconazole, voriconazole, and isavuconazole. Genotypes TR34/L98H/T289A/I364V/G448S mutant showed a consistent phenotype to the clinical strains, which are highly resistant to voriconazole but susceptible to itraconazole. In this study, we show that molecular dynamics simulations of amino acid substitutions in the cyp51A gene correlate to the structure–function relationship of in vitro phenotype.

title: Antifungal Activity and Resistance Risk of Cyclobutrifluram against Fusarium solani, the Causal Agent of Peanut Root Rot
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Peanut root rot (PRR), caused by Fusarium solani, is a common and destructive disease. Cyclobutrifluram exhibits antifungal activity against Fusarium spp., yet its bioactivity and resistance risk against F. solani remain unclear. In this study, the EC50 values of cyclobutrifluram against 155 F. solani strains ranged from 0.0279 to 0.1102 μg/mL, with a mean of 0.0513 ± 0.0170 μg/mL. Treatment with cyclobutrifluram significantly inhibited conidial production and germination, reduced succinate dehydrogenase (SDH) activity, increased hyphal branching, and shortened the distance between septa or cell nuclei. Cyclobutrifluram provided excellent control over PRR. Seven laboratory-generated cyclobutrifluram-resistant mutants showed no or slight fitness penalties and exhibited positive cross-resistance only with pydiflumetofen, indicating a moderate-to-high resistance risk. Resistance to cyclobutrifluram in F. solani was conferred by four SDH substitutions (FsSdhBH248Y, FsSdhC1A83V, FsSdhC2A85V, and FsSdhDD184G), which was confirmed by molecular docking and gene replacement. This study provides crucial insights for developing effective control strategies to manage PRR.
summary: This study examines the antifungal activity of cyclobutrifluram against Fusarium solani, the causal agent of peanut root rot. The results show that cyclobutrifluram exhibits potent antifungal activity against 155 strains of F. solani, with EC50 values ranging from 0.0279 to 0.1102 μg/mL. Treatment with cyclobutrifluram substantially reduced conidial production and germination, reduced succinate dehydrogenase activity, increased hyphal branching, and shortened the distance between septa or cell nuclei. Cyclobutrifluram provided excellent control over peanut root rot.  However, the study also identifies a moderate-to-high resistance risk to cyclobutrifluram in F. solani, with seven laboratory-generated resistant mutants showing no or slight fitness penalties. The resistance was conferred by four SDH substitutions, which was confirmed by molecular docking and gene replacement. This finding highlights the potential for the development of resistance to cyclobutrifluram in F. solani, emphasizing the need for effective control strategies to manage peanut root rot. This tension between control and resistance underscores the need for a nuanced understanding of the ecological and social contexts in which disease management strategies are implemented.

title: Efficacy of Ipflufenoquin against Strawberry Gray Mold: Insights from AlphaFold- Based Structural Modeling and Genome-Wide Transcriptomic Analysis
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Gray mold caused by Botrytis cinerea significantly threatens strawberry production. This study evaluated the efficacy of ipflufenoquin, a novel dihydroorotate dehydrogenase (DHODH) inhibitor, against fungal pathogens isolated from Korean strawberry fields in 2023. Ipflufenoquin demonstrated a high in vitro sensitivity to B. cinerea and broad activity against other pathogens. Fruit and greenhouse trials confirmed its robust control of gray mold, including strains resistant to multiple fungicide classes. However, treatment shifted the fungal community, promoting less sensitive genera, such as Cladosporium and Rhizopus. Structural modeling with AlphaFold2 and molecular docking confirmed that ipflufenoquin binds to the quinone binding tunnel of DHODH, correlating binding affinity with susceptibility. Additionally, RNA-seq analysis revealed that ipflufenoquin suppresses primary metabolic pathways while triggering a robust stress response, up-regulating detoxification and efflux transporter genes. This integrated study confirms the efficacy of ipflufenoquin against gray mold and elucidates its molecular impacts, offering essential data for sustainable management strategies.

source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT The substantial increase in fungal diseases, the limited availability of antifungal drugs, and rising resistance to existing treatments highlight the urgent need for developing novel antifungal drugs. Natural products, known for their diverse bioactivities and unique structures, remain critical sources for antifungal drug discovery. In this study, we aimed to identify novel antifungal compounds from soil microbes and isolated a novel 28-membered polyene macrolide, compound 1 , from Kitasatospora melanogena . This compound demonstrated potent antifungal activity, with MICs of 4–16 μg/mL against Aspergillus fumigatus , Aspergillus flavus , Candida albicans , and Cryptococcus neoformans . Treatment with compound 1 led to significant growth reduction and disruption of the cell wall and membrane in A. fumigatus compared to the wild-type. To understand the underlying mechanism, we performed a transcriptomic analysis of A. fumigatus exposed to compound 1 , revealing a substantial downregulation of genes involved in cell wall and membrane biogenesis, as well as those encoding integral membrane proteins and multidrug transporters. Additionally, compound 1 induced oxidative stress, leading to elevated reactive oxygen species levels. These multifaceted mechanisms highlight the potential of K. melanogena natural products in the development of novel antifungal agents. title: Nano-Stimulated Immunity: Synthesis and Functionalization of CuS Induce Multilevel Defense Responses against Fusarium in Tomato (Solanum lycopersicum)
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: This study investigated how doping-modified copper sulfide (CuS) micronanoparticles (MNPs) influence tomato resistance against fungal pathogens. Three cuboidal CuS MNPs─undoped (CuS), iron-doped (Fe-CuS), and cerium-doped (Ce-CuS)─were foliarly applied to Fusarium-infected plants in a greenhouse study. Fe-CuS led to the highest Cu accumulation in leaves─15.7 and 158.4% higher than undoped CuS and Ce-CuS, respectively, likely due to its positive charge facilitating stronger electrostatic interactions and more efficient NPs uptake. Compared to the untreated control, the Fe-CuS foliar application resulted in a 487.7% increase in shoot biomass and a 36.8% reduction in wilt damage through activation of jasmonic acid/ethylene signaling, indicating a dual role of CuS MNPs as both a micronutrient carrier and an immune stimulant. Importantly, copper amine oxidases (CuAOs) activation may link Cu homeostasis to stress-induced H2O2 production, indicating a novel mechanism for nanoparticle-enabled plant immunity. These findings underscore the significant potential for CuS MNPs as an alternative to conventional copper-based fungicides, though long-term environmental behavior and life cycle impacts warrant further evaluation.

Three types of CuS micronanoparticles were tested: undoped (CuS), iron-doped (Fe-CuS), and cerium-doped (Ce-CuS). The iron-doped CuS particles led to the highest accumulation of copper in tomato leaves, likely due to their positive charge facilitating stronger interactions with the plant cells. The Fe-CuS particles also resulted in a significant increase in shoot biomass and a reduction in wilt damage, indicating that CuS micronanoparticles can stimulate plant immunity. The activation of copper amine oxidases may play a role in linking copper homeostasis to stress-induced hydrogen peroxide production, suggesting a novel mechanism for nanoparticle-enabled plant immunity. These findings suggest that CuS micronanoparticles could be used as an alternative to conventional copper-based fungicides, but further evaluation is needed to assess their long-term environmental impacts.   The use of CuS micronanoparticles as an immune stimulant in plants shares some similarities with the use of titanium nanoparticles in chitosan nanocapsules to inhibit pathogenic microbes. Both approaches involve the use of nanoparticles to enhance plant resistance to pathogens, but the specific mechanisms and materials used differ significantly.

title: A combined genetic and chemical approach for identifying novel antifungal compounds against Fusarium graminearum
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Chemical fungicides act by targeting specific proteins or pathways, known as modes of action (MoAs). title: Homologous Overexpression of Phosphatidate Phosphatase (Lipin) in the Oleaginous Fungus Mucor circinelloides WJ11 Enhances Lipid Accumulation under Static Solid Cultivation and Submerged Fermentation
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Lipin, a phosphatidic acid phosphatase, catalyzes the conversion of phosphatidic acid to diacylglycerol, a key step in triacylglycerol (TAG) biosynthesis, and acts as a transcriptional coregulator of lipid metabolism. In this study, the Lipin-encoding gene (McLipin) was overexpressed in Mucor circinelloides WJ11 to evaluate its impact on lipid accumulation under submerged (SmF) and solid-state fermentation (SSF). Under SSF, McLipin overexpression increased cell dry weight by 19% in spores and 36.9% in mycelia compared to the control strain. Total fatty acid (TFA) content increased by 35.7% in mycelia, while in spores it increased from 10% to 18% of dry cell weight, indicating a substantial enhancement in lipid yield. Fatty acid profiling showed elevated proportions of C16:0, C18:2, and C18:3 and a reduced C18:1 content. RT-qPCR indicated that McLipin expression peaked at 24 h under SSF, coinciding with upregulation of ACC, FAS, cME, and NADPH-generating genes. These results suggest that McLipin overexpression reprograms lipid metabolism, significantly enhancing TAG biosynthesis under SSF for potential industrial lipid production.
summary: The source report describes research on the oleaginous fungus Mucor circinelloides WJ11, where the Lipin-encoding gene (McLipin) was overexpressed to enhance lipid accumulation under static solid cultivation and submerged fermentation. This study found that McLipin overexpression increased cell dry weight and total fatty acid content in both spores and mycelia compared to the control strain. The fatty acid profiling showed elevated proportions of certain fatty acids, such as C16:0, C18:2, and C18:3, and a reduced C18:1 content. RT-quantitative polymerase chain reaction analysis indicated that McLipin expression peaked at 24 hours under static solid cultivation, coinciding with increased activity of of certain genes involved in lipid metabolism.  This research signal highlights the potential for genetic manipulation to enhance lipid production in oleaginous fungi, which could have implications for industrial lipid production. The findings suggest that McLipin overexpression reprograms lipid metabolism, significantly enhancing triacylglycerol biosynthesis under static solid cultivation. The relationship between Lipin and lipid metabolism in Mucor circinelloides WJ11 is analogous to the role of GSNOR in regulating nitric oxide homeostasis and aflatoxin biosynthesis in Aspergillus flavus, where GSNOR deletion resulted in significantly elevated nitric oxide levels and heightened sensitivity to exogenous nitric oxide stress. The capacity of fungi to accumulate lipids, like Mucor circinelloides WJ11, highlights the duality of these organisms as both a threat and a resource, their ability to metabolize diverse materials making them both a pathogen and a potential industrial saviour.

title: Beyond Fumigatus: a molecular portrait of clinical Aspergillus diversity, pathogenicity, and antifungal resistance
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Aspergillus infection poses a major clinical challenge, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, with invasive diseases associated with high mortality. While Aspergillus fumigatus remains the predominant species causing human infections, recent studies highlight the growing clinical significance of lesser-known and cryptic Aspergillus species, which often exhibit reduced susceptibility to standard antifungal therapies. In this study, we analyzed 196 clinical Aspergillus isolates from 107 patients treated at the NIH Clinical Center between 2019 and 2022. A total of 38 Aspergillus species across 11 taxonomic sections were identified, with non-fumigatus and cryptic species accounting for 77.1% of all isolates. The most frequently recovered species were A. fumigatus sensu stricto (22.9%), A. sydowii (8.7%), A. calidoustus (7.1%), A. nidulans (6.6%), A. tanneri (6.1%), and A. terreus (5.6%). Species-level identification was achieved in 43% of isolates using matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS). In contrast, PCR sequencing confirmed species identity in over 88% of isolates by targeting the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region of rDNA, 81% using the β-tubulin gene, and 68% using the calmodulin gene. Antifungal susceptibility testing showed that olorofim had the lowest minimal inhibitory concentrations across species. In contrast, the activity of triazoles and amphotericin B was variable, particularly against A. tanneri, A. calidoustus, and A. sydowii. title: Production of ETP-Type (Epipolythiodioxopiperazine) Mycotoxins in Clinical Fungal Isolates
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Gliotoxin, an epipolythiodioxopiperazine (ETP) toxin, has been reported in several fungal species, but its distribution remains unclear. We analyzed 140 clinical isolates from two major hospitals using HPLC and LC-MS/MS to assess gliotoxin production. Gliotoxin was detected only in Aspergillus fumigatus isolates, with no production observed in any other species under multiple culture conditions. Molecular networking and comparative genomics revealed distinct ETP-related pathways in non-A. fumigatus species, including aspirochlorine derivatives in Aspergillus flavus and aranotin-related metabolites in Aspergillus terreus. These findings clarify species-specific ETP profiles and confirm A. fumigatus as the sole gliotoxin producer among the isolates examined.

title: Antibacterial and Cytotoxic Decahydrofluorene-Class Alkaloids from the Marine-Derived Fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Eight new decahydrofluorene-class alkaloids, pyrrospirones R-Y (1-8), together with 13 known analogues (9-21) were isolated from the marine-derived fungal strain Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512. Their structures were determined by extensive spectroscopic analysis, and their absolute configurations were established by quantum chemical calculations of electronic circular dichroism (ECD) spectra, by a comparison of experimental ECD spectra, or by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Compound 1 rarely contains an oxime hydroxy with a 6/5/6/5/6/13 polycyclic system. A plausible biosynthetic pathway for 1 and 2 was proposed. Biologically, compounds 1, 4, 6, 8, 10-12, 14-15, 18-19, and 21 had cytotoxicity against human cancer cell lines A549 and HCT116 with IC50 values of 7.3-79.3 μM, and 1, 4, 6, 11, 15, 18, and 21 also showed significant inhibitory activity against six pathogenic bacteria with MIC values of 1.6-13.0 μg/mL. Their structure-bioactivity relationship was also discussed.

title: Advancing mold identification in the routine laboratory, performance of smartphone-based imaging and a newly developed convolutional neural network
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Mold identification in clinical diagnostics is traditionally labor-intensive and is dependent on expert interpretation. MoldVision is a deep-learning approach that uses smartphone images of mold cultures to automate identification. We analyzed 161 clinical isolates across four common mold genera: Penicillium spp., Aspergillus spp. (with A. flavus and A. fumigatus), Fusarium spp., and Cladosporium spp. Daily images were captured from the top and bottom of culture plates over 5 days using a standardized smartphone setup, generating over 4,000 images. We trained three variations of Visual Geometry Group 16 (VGG16) convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and benchmarked the best-performing model (VGG16 with dual classification heads) against LightGBM models trained on pre-extracted features and human expert assessments at various time points. The best-performing VGG16 model achieved a mean (SD) AUROC of 92.7% ± 1.8% and sensitivity of 68.7% ± 2.6% across all species. Here, the performance in identifying Cladosporium spp. was best (AUROC of 99.9% ± 0.1%, fivefold cross-validation mean and SD). Regarding the evaluations over time, early-stage classification (days 1–2) was challenging (F1-score 38.8% ± 3.5% across all species) but improved significantly on days 3–5 (F1 92.1% ± 2.8% across all species). Compared to experts, MoldVision consistently showed superior performance, particularly in mature cultures, detecting subtle morphological features earlier and more accurately. Our results demonstrate that CNNs integrated with low-cost smartphone imaging can reliably classify mold species in routine diagnostics, outperforming human experts in many cases. This approach offers a practical and scalable solution for laboratories lacking specialized mycology expertise, especially in resource-limited settings. title: GSNOR is essential for nitric oxide homeostasis and involved in aflatoxin biosynthesis and pathogenicity in Aspergillus flavus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Applied and Environmental Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Nitric oxide (NO) is an important biological signaling molecule. S-nitrosoglutathione reductase (GSNOR), a master regulator of NO signaling, regulates various biological processes. However, little is known about the role of GSNOR in Aspergillus flavus. Here, we identified a gene encoding GSNOR in this aflatoxigenic fungus and demonstrated that GSNOR shows activity during the critical life cycle stages, including spore germination, hyphal growth, and conidiogenesis. We found that GSNOR plays a crucial role in NO homeostasis, as GSNOR deletion resulted in significantly elevated NO levels and heightened sensitivity to exogenous NO stress. Our findings indicate that GSNOR is crucial for maintaining both NO homeostasis and reactive oxygen species (ROS) balance and plays an essential role in fungal development, pathogenicity, and aflatoxin biosynthesis.
